title: The Physics of Frisbee Flight
abstract: An exploration into how lift, drag, and angular momentum make a Frisbee soar across the Great Lawn.
caption: Courtesy of Brophy Research Journal
paragraphs: Alex Johnson ‘26 investigated the science behind Frisbee throws during lunch breaks. The study examines how changes in angle of attack and spin rate affect distance.
The research also compares different Frisbee brands, concluding that shape and rim thickness significantly change aerodynamic stability.

title: Mathematical Models of Coffee Cooling
abstract: We explore Newton’s Law of Cooling as applied to coffee temperature over time.
caption: Courtesy of Brophy Research Journal
paragraphs: Sarah Martinez ‘25 investigated how Newton’s Law of Cooling applies to everyday life by tracking coffee cooling rates.
The research demonstrated how exponential models can predict real-world heat loss in beverages.

title: AI-Powered Plant Growth Analysis
abstract: We applied computer vision to monitor and predict plant growth patterns in the Brophy greenhouse.
caption: Courtesy of Brophy Research Journal
paragraphs: Daniel Kim ‘24 developed an AI-based method for tracking plant growth in the school greenhouse.
By using Python and OpenCV, the team measured leaf size and color changes over time to predict growth trends.
